content.description: Stand start with small hands up to a slopey hold. Super slabby and really fun!
content.location: Number 12 in Peter Dodge's Guide to Bouldering.

content.description: Route #7 in the Urban Cragger. Just to the right of The dihedral warm up problem. Stand start using slot and sloped rail. High feet and use diagonal seam to the top.
content.location: Obvious triangular pocket and sloped rail. Just to the right of the classical dihedral warm up.

content.description: Same start as Unknown 3, but move towards the arete and then to top.
Starting at the horizontal  above a cresent dish, climb up  using the diagonal seam.  Seam can also be aided at C2.
Standing start low on two flakes, dynamic moves take you to the top.
Sit start on the obvious arete and climb up left of the arete.
Just left of Stump Chump...Start on the holds on and left of the horizontal and climb the crimps to the top.
Start on the corner, move right and up into the shallow dihedral.
Feels more like a scramble than a climb. Straight up the slab face to the top.
content.location: Number 13 in Peter Dodge's Guide to Bouldering.

content.description: I don't know if this has been done before so I won't take credit for it. Awkward sit start at Crimper's Delight (right side of boulder) and work left on good rails and crimps until you top out at the left arete, the same top-out as Chump Unknown. The crux for me was the last move because of how long the boulder is, but it's super fun!
content.location: Side of boulder facing the road. Sit start on the rightmost jug near the ground.

content.description: Same Start as delight. Move right to decent sloper. Stand up and finish
Sit start on obvious jug ledge. Make a left hand move to the rail and match. Big move to small crimp, shuffle feet, and proceed to send.
content.location: Front of First Street Boulder. Right of the chump routes.

content.description: Start the same as Chump Unknown but instead of finishing in the shallow dihedral continue into the starting crimps on unknown #3 problem finishing with the fun dyno.   Adds a more difficult finish to Chump Unknown making it a solid V5 in my opinion.
content.location: start the same as Chump Unknown and finish on Unknown #3

content.description: Start on Stump Chump (or just stand using the bomber undercling and huge left sidepull). Work up a move or two, then use that core strength to press into a wicked double gaston. Fancy footwork bring one into the shallow wanna-be dihedral to the right of the arete, and perhaps another gaston. Either stay in the shallow area, or utilize the arete on the left. Both exits make this semi-traverse the most classic line on the First Street Boulder (in my silly opinion).
content.protection: The landing can actually be kinda sketch, as small boulders start to line the base on this side, so several crash pads a couple spotters are recommended, but not necessary if you're as awesome (stupid?) as Egg and me.
content.location: This is the proudest line on the steepest arete with the huge chalked starting holds, where the boulders meet the dirt, road facing.

content.description: This is the first boulder that is recomended to anyone new to the area and looking for an afternoon session.  Located right off of first street about half a block north/east of Whopee Wall, this erratic has a few good lines from V0 to V6ish.  Landings can be protected easily with pads and the walk off is nice and mellow.  As with all urban areas is Duluth, glass and bums can be an issue...
